commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Place for grape nuts?  (4)
2. "Also also...," for short  (3)
3. It'll make you laugh, it'll make you cry  (7)
4. Masters of bad impersonations?  (8)(7)
5. Do-to-do delivery?  (6)


NAPA
PPS
DRAMEDY
IDENTITY THIEVES
OCTAVE
KEMOSABE? REALLY? What's next? "Heap Big Spirit?" Really disappointed. And, yes, I know that a non-indigenous judge said it was perfectly fine. Okay, that makes it just fine. Just. Why?
Cute theme. Seemed easier than the typical easy Monday.
Apparently Big Toothpaste has cut back on its advertising budget and I, for one, am imploring them to get it together!
I didn't finish Sunday!  It's  only 6:30 p.m. on Sunday.  Where's my puzzle?  I'll  do Monday on Monday not Sunday evening.
Just set a new Monday best! Out of curiosity, long time/super speedy solvers: what’s your Monday record?
DASANI and LARGE COKE? Are we missing some sponsorship disclaimer?

Nice Monday puzzle.

Definitely did not see
that revealer coming.

Michael, was the 
LARGE COKE
a CLASSIC?
New personal best. 3:40
What s twist the mini was harder than the regular today

Very nicely crafted puzzle, Mr. Lieberman, and what a great find for a theme! It had never before occured to me that these nursery rhymes all have something in common. I also greatly enjoyed the long down answers which added a certain something special to the grid. Thank you for the puzzle, and for sending me down memory lane with Anita Baker, the perfect listen for a rainy, lazy, Sunday afternoon: https://youtu.be/GNDuWcLI5fg?feature=shared
I was 3 seconds off my best today... Excellent work!

Little known facts…

JACK felt down and broke his crown when he tripped over a DOG TOY

HUMPTY DUMPTY fell off the wall because he was TIPSY 

LONDON BRIDGE is falling down because of overaggressive construction DEADLINES 
 
Fun theme!

And I trust OCTOPUSES will be plurally pleasing.

Woo-hoo I successfully solved it with just the across clues for the first time.
The across pass was getting me pretty much everything, at least on the top 3/4. So I decided to go for it.
I think I've seriously attempted this feat about 15 times before.
A PB.  This being a Monday it is my fastest for any day!

Wow big PB for me at sub-3 minutes. Hard to imagine I will ever beat that. I wish when you got a PB it would remind you what your previous PB was? If that exists, please share! I can’t remember exactly what it was.

Fast and fun!! It was a new personal best for me in a time I never thought I could achieve. 

It probably helped that I did it on my computer instead of my phone app, which is what I usually do early week puzzles on but even so, this one seemed to fly. But not in a boring way. It seemed bright and cheery and breezy! I really enjoyed it and never thought before about those nursery rhymes all having falls in common. 

My favorite though is the clue for Sunrises. "They brighten everybody's day!" So sweet! 

Though I pretty quickly plugged in the theme answers, the revealer was not immediately apparent. I didn't know they called the world series that but it was quickly revealed by the crossings.

In other news, I'm still scratching my head over what on earth I could have possibly written that the emus objected to yesterday when I tried to post something three different times with minor adjustments in each to try to get them through.  It's just funny because I've learned so many facts about emus through the puzzles, but still they are such a mystery. Oh well! There are far greater mysteries to ponder, one supposes. 

Cheers to a new week, all!! Since it's still Sunday night, I'll toast you with a 🍸 instead of my morning poison of choice, which is a 🥤LARGE diet COKE.
New PB of 5min 24! Not the fastest out there but proud nonetheless. Cute entries and a satisfying solve.
Pb 18:50 here
PB 3:55! My first ever solve under 4 minutes.
5:41! A new record for me!
Funny. Thank you.

I do the crossword as a relief from all the things in life that must be acted on quickly so I’m never in a rush. But many congratulations to all those for whom the time is important! 

Spoken like someone who doesn’t have a time worth mentioning :)

I once worked on a farm that had a ferocious pair of goats (really!) that stayed with the cows at night, so when I accidentally read “cattle attacker” instead of “castle attacker” on 4D, I didn’t even hesitate to put a Goose on Maine’s flag instead of a MOOSE.
At 5:55, five seconds off my PB about a year into solving, I was feeling pretty good until I saw some of the bonkers times being posted here.  Sheesh, guys!

I am so unhappy with recent changes to games, particularly for crossword.  It seems like I am forced to go to the NYT games app if I get the the crossword late in the day or want to use archive.  And crossword in the app isn’t good (at least on my phone).  I can’t find anywhere to contact to lodge a complaint or get help.

Can anyone help?

Thanks!

Jack and Jill's last trip pailed in comparison.

(These puns are hill areas.)

Smug report: I managed to complete it without looking at the Down clues! Monday Yay! 

I hope you all have a wonderful day!

I found this to be one of the easiest and thus most relaxing Monday puzzles ever: I was a few seconds off my personal best time despite not understanding the theme, mostly due to only knowing one themed entry, HUMPTY DUMPTY. I have heard the phrase JACK AND JILL somewhere but never knew it was a title, ditto LONDON BRIDGE. We have our own Polish nursery rhymes, obviously: "Lokomotywa" by Julian Tuwim is the best known one, but I began to learn English when I was starting school, so not at an age for nursery rhymes any more. HUMPTY DUMPTY I learned from TV, and not children's TV, either: lines from it feature often enough in film and series dialogue.

Also, to me a FALL CLASSIC would be a STEW 🤣. I've never heard of it in a sporting context, but I'm not into American sports, at all.
Finally broke 1-minute! Didn't need the down clues so flew right through.
Stopped doing my daily crossword for the past couple of months because life got in the way, but finished in 5 minutes today, about a minute over my PB...happy to be back!

What a lovely grid. Pleasant memories of reciting the rhymes with the kids interspersed with interesting crosses. The only clue I didn’t automatically know was 59A, being a sports thing.

Our clocks went back an hour on Sunday so we now have daylight at 7am again. For a while anyway. So much nicer than getting up in the dark, though I tend to miss the SUNRISES.

One of the most fun Monday puzzles that I can remember.  

Well done, Michael.
Many nursery rhymes have their origins in political, or other, satire, thinly veiled. Might this be the reason why falling is a recurring theme?

Really fun Monday puzzle. Not a record time for me, but it all fell together fairly smoothly. Needed some down crosses for the reveal to dawn on me so that was the last thing I filled in. Just a nice 'aha' moment when I finally got that. Couldn't ask for anything more. 

A couple of quite interesting puzzle finds today. I'll put those in replies. 

...

I am going to be frankly negative in hopes that the editors will pay attention.   IMO:For the last six weeks or so, the Monday puzzles have been banal, repetitive and, boring.  Today's nursery rhymes theme seemed aimed at   kindergarteners. I wonder if  bots are creating them.  Easy peasy  Gold is not a well-earned reward.
fun, easy, and some clever clues--a perfect monday puzzle imo

I'm guessing that some days the Tricky Clues column is more difficult to write than others...

.

I tried to figure out the revealer by leaving it blank after filling in the theme answers.  First, I tried to get it without seeing its clue – nada after trying hard to come up with angles.  

Then I looked at the revealer’s clue, and still nada, after more serious digging.  

Finally, I revealed one letter at a time from the beginning, and when FALL appeared, the answer finally hit me.

My immediate reactions: 
•	“Oh, excellent and clever!” (with a smile). 
•	“I should have at least figured out ‘FALL’” (with a “Dang!”). 
•	“Got me good!” (with a nod of respect).  
•	“Great brain workout!” (with an Ahh!”). 

The rest of the puzzle was a dash, and there is thrill in that.  Plus, there was a pair of sweet serendipities: Four palindromes (ELLE, ANNA, EKE, ALA) and two French words that sound like English letters (EAU , ELLE).

So, a package of Crosslandia goodness for me, Michael Lieberman -- a most lovely way to start the day.  Thank you, sir!

Something tumbles poetically


(and with that atomic-alarm-clock ring of familiarity, as Yankees and Dodgers face off, like in the days of (my) yore.)
“The hazards of decaying infrastructure” —loved that. Very quick Monday, nice clean clues. Thank you for a good start to the week.
New personal best at 3min today! sub 3 is coming soon, I can feel it....

Now this is more like it. Lovely puzzle, with a clever payoff.
May the puzzles for the rest of the week be equally fun.

Bravo, Mr. Lieberman. Encore!
My first ever sub-two minute puzzle!

So much puckish humor in the cluing of the theme answers.  I loved this!

I wondered if I could figure out the revealer ahead of time?  MOTHER GOOSES YOU was the closest I could come.  That's definitely not it.

I also wondered if the theme answers occurred to Michael first or if the revealer did.  It can work both ways as I well know, but sometimes you have wonderful theme answer ideas and no revealer that works.  That might be the time to have all theme answers and no revealer.  Which would this be?

FALL CLASSIC blew me away.  It's perfect -- and I bet that absolutely no one saw it coming.  The double meaning of FALL is the icing on the cake.

A delightful and witty Monday!

I'd like to be under the sea In an OCTUPUS's garden In the shade We would be warm below the storm In our little hideaway beneath the waves Resting our head on the seabed In an octopus's garden near a cave https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=De1LCQvbqV4 The puzzle was surely titled Child's Play? a delightful Monday. Thanks, Michael.

"The Bible has an Old and New one" -

The correct clue would be either "Some Bibles have an Old and New one" or "Christian Bibles have an Old and New one".

Oh geez, more baseball. I remain steadfastly bored by the sport.

Thankfully, this puzzle was much more fun than a baseball game! Bravo!
Came so close to beating my record today!

Why the obsession with how fast you can do the puzzle? Relax. Enjoy the clever cluing. I don't think constructors try to make a puzzle in the fastest time possible... or do they? (I'm not a constructor.)

[Nursery rhyme about a Sisyphean odyssey]

Neat find on the theme with a very nicely repurposed revealer.






ITSY BITSY SPIDER
Lots of fun and very clever
A fun reminder that a quick solve can be rewarding on several levels.  Enjoyed this.

Nice to see Phylum Mollusca featured so prominently. And with an acceptable plural, too! 




OK, I'll clam up now.
I'm not saying this was a perfect Monday puzzle, but I'm NOT NOT saying it either. (For anyone who didn't quite get the "double negative" clue.)

Got the 3 themers and solved the reveal with just the C.  Do I have to fill in those others squares now?    Just kidding.   Very fun and clever and a tie in (sort of) with today's Strands.  

Strands #239
“Fall fun”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵

One of the words came hard as it just did not seem to fit with the others but who knows.   

No spoilers for Strands until after the View All Replies bar.
I am here because news of the Trump love fest at MSG has me absolutely terrified.

Actually, there are several brands that have shifted the meaning of their initialisms besides STP. KFC TCBY ESPN YM https://slate.com/business/2004/05/what-does-kfc-stand-for-now.html I am also reminded that I learned in a recent Wordplay column that it's an acronym if you pronounce the string of letters as if it's a word, and an initialism if you just say the letters. So for example, a TLA is not one (an acronym, that is).

A fun puzzle connecting to the World Series. Being a lifelong Yankee fan, I know that the tables will turn now that the Bronx Bombers are home for the next few games.

As far as those solvers who consider themselves “above” such an easy puzzle, I ask simply, did you start solving crossword puzzles with only Th-Sat?
Let’s let everyone have a win now and then.

Concerning STP, it is frequently used in puzzles and clues in ways usually referencing auto racing.
The origin of the letters in its name are varied in explanation.  Years ago we used to consider it based on “Stop That Ping”.
Excellent puzzle!!!
This was my first-ever crossword puzzle. It took me about 45 minutes, and I had to get quite a few hints towards the end. Still, it was fun!
I got them all, bar the taro dish. Unknown words were solved by the crossers. Almost too easy! Given that sometimes I hardly get any, I'm grateful for small mercies.
First time I've ever gotten a puzzle in under 10 minutes (even if it is only Monday...) !!

Thank you, Mr. Lieberman, for a very pleasant start to the week! The difficulty was perfect for a Monday, and the theme and revealer were clever (& a lot of fun). Really looking forward to more of your work!

Well, I've finally recovered from seeing 91A in yesterdays puzzle and was happy to see a more appropriate mention at 4A.  It was nice to see my family and I mentioned in a way that gives us the respect we are due.

My best time ever! Happy Monday.
(Vote 🗳️.)

I’ve heard that MOOSE burgers are delicious, similar to bison. Probably best not to over season when adding salt and pepper TOTASTE. But that happens sometimes if one is a little TIPSY. On the other hand, I tried POI once and I will not EAT it again.

Thanks Mr. Lieberman for the enjoyable solve! Also, your son is exceptionally adorable in your profile photo on Xwordinfo but are you sure he is a Dodgers fan?

Looks like lots of people are setting new PBs today, including me! Finally smashed through the 4 min barrier, which was one of my personal milestones this year. 

Slowly but surely making my way to a sub 2 min solve, might have to switch to desktop so I can type faster lol.
Finally broke 5 minutes with this one!
Wasn’t there someone going for a 1000-day streak today? Any news on that front?
Nice Monday puzzle and nice that the Yanks & Dodgers are in the World Series. How evah! Da Bums is still in da wrong city and Robinson was out in '55!
This was my first googleless solve! I don't expect to see much more of that (except maybe other Mondays) but I don't feel like that takes away from crosswords as a way to spend time for me.

My stats say I finished this in 4:09. I'd like that to be true, as it would be my best time for any crossword so far, but the actual puzzle page shows the real time: 6:15. 
Why?

I finished faster than I ever have before on a Monday.  Not as fast as others, of course, but I'm delighted I was able to enter without a typo.  I love nursery rhymes and the history behind them. I enjoyed this puzzle. Thank you Mr. Lieberman and NYT crossword team. As far as your favorite to win the FALL CLASSIC, I don't have a dog in this race, but like to root for the underdog, so "GO YANKEES"

Y'all have fun! Cheers from Texas.

Going to bed happy and looking forward to the SUNRISES because I just got my fastest time and I couldn’t be happier!!!
Thanks for the solve.

@Lewis 

Not the entry clued, "What might be included in an act of congress"?  😉

@Mr Dave -- Oh, I liked that clue a lot, but it wasn't in my top five.  The "congress" pun has been used several times, and I put a premium on freshness and originality.  When it was first used in the Times, in November of 2022, as [What might prompt a run for congress] for LIBIDO, it most certainly made my list.
@Lewis Re; # 3. also could be wry humor/ Dad joke.

TLC,

Point noted, but that was the Sunday puzzle.
These are the Monday puzzle comments.

@Barry Ancona 
While what you say is absolutely correct 
I am at a bit of a loss as to why you felt obliged to say it. 
Although there are obviously many who agree that the comments must be rigorously policed as you have 15 reccos as I write this!
Interesting

@NH - There are lots of solvers who only try beginning of the week puzzles. They would have no way of understanding what the OP was referring to without a reply such as BA’s. Just a suggested explanation.

@TLC I'm sorry you got pooh-poohed for posting a Sunday puzzle comment a day late. This is a pretty persnickety group. I can just hear "Teacher, TLC is commenting on Sunday puzzle!" I don't have anything to say about KEMOSABE, but I found the Wordplay from the last time it appeared. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/13/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2018-07-14.html Caitlin had some words about it. Kind of interesting.

@NH 

It's not at all unusual for certain posters to make posts like this.

That's why I'm nearly done with posting here.

It's a corrupted environment.  Massively hurtful posts are allowed to stay up, posts that react that that hurt are taken down.

@Aaron

Haha. Hopefully P&G can start a GoFundMe to keep themselves afloat (like Ivory soap?).

hywel,

Sunday is in the archive, 
where it always is after 6 p.m. ET.

Go back and finish it;
we'll see you tomorrow.
@hywel If you finish the Sunday puzzle it before midnight EDT on Sunday, it will count toward your active streak if you have one, even though Monday's puzzle becomes available at 6pm EDT on Sunday.

@Michael Weiland 
I don't think there is a deadline at midnight; as long as you finish the puzzles in order, your streak is retained. It will temporarily show as zero until you catch up though, which is a little disconcerting.
Lauren, This is my Monday record. It has been for quite some time. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h81Ojd3d2rY
@Lauren Today was my personal best! 3:26
@Lauren 3:40, today
@Barry Ancona Too predictable...as was Justin's rejoinder. Here's my submission: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CKF-_FEay60

@Lauren 

My serious answer is 2:33.

It was April 27, 2020.  A quick review of it from the Archive shows that practically every Across answer was super obvious ([Barbed-___fence], anyone?).  (It also helped to know things like who was in "The Wizard of Oz".)  I doubt I looked at too many of the Downs at all, although I see one or two spots where I might have.

I probably did it on my desktop, where I get my best times.  This time probably approaches the limit of what I can do, based on my reading and typing skills.

And I probably didn't set out to set a new personal best, but most likely I picked up speed as it seemed likely that it would happen.

And even though you didn't ask, I once did a 5x5 Mini in 8 seconds. I don't remember (and am not going to check) when.

As they say, it's not bragging if it's true.
@Steve L I went back and tried the 4/27/20 puzzle (albeit on my phone) and got 4:17. Not a PB, but top 5

@Lauren Monday (and really any day) Personal Best for me too, and my first finish under 3 minutes. While we're playing DJ, this is the song that comes to mind: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8yteMugRAc0 - though it's tough to listen to if you know its backstory.

@Lauren 
Statistics say my pb is 3:17, but today at 4:20 was about as fast as I can get solving on my phone. I can only type so fast without fat-fingering a wrong answer. This felt like a very swift smooth solve with no mistakes.
@Barry Ancona my Monday record https://youtu.be/c1GxjzHm5us?si=v8OK67-P6-88o7Ok
@Barry Ancona Thanks for planting that ear worm, Barry.

@Evan 

God forbid America should have any higher standard than making hundreds of billions of dollars for tens of people.

@Red Carpet 
"Can’t forget the oil." Gosh, I hope not. There is almost nothing that is produced where oil is not in the supply chain.

@Steven M. 
Same here!

Andue
I find minis constructed by Wyna Liu a bit more twisty than those of some of the other constructors.

@Andue I don't Mini much, but given the extra time left over by the quick CW, I gave it a go.

So ATTED is a word now? 🙄
@Alpha Bravo - Yes, there is a verb “to at (someone)”. After making a joke or saying something that steps on slippery ground, the speaker will add: “Don’t at me!”

@Wayne Harrison 

👍🏽
@Katie Amazing PB! Congrats.

@Katie
At the bottom of the page, you’ll find the records for your best time average time and slowest time. There’s a little graphic as well.

@Francis 

Haha! Actually, not so much! 

I just love the clue and think it's very sweet and charming....  but I am definitely much more of a sunset person. 

I can't remember the last time I willingly saw a sunrise! 😁

🌃🦉

@Kat O 
That's the exact time I got, too!  For arthritic fumbly figured me, that's not bad.  I found Monday's puzzle great fun!
@Wes Nice work!
@Justin wanna compare longest time taken? :)

lioncitysolver,

I’m up for that. First one to post their time loses!

:)

(atomick… atomock… atomick…)
@Justin and when you speed through you miss the joy of the clever clues. I actually feel cheated if I fill in a whole corner on the across and don’t get to see the down clues. Here’s for slowpokes!

@KLW

I agree 100%! So glad there's someone else who feels the same way about seeing the down clues too!

@sbs 
Like @Andrzej I find it impossible to type that quickly even when I know all the answers, so well done you on your great time. For me it’s maybe an age thing, but also I enjoy the journey, not just the end goal.

@Andrzej 
I also use a stylus on my iPad. I got sick of ‘fat finger’ errors. I swear the virtual keypad is much smaller now; my kids say it’s because I’m old. The cheek!

@Helen Wright 

I'm not sure it has to have anything to do with age - the perception of key size, placement and spacing is a very personal thing, and if your device's keyboard is off your ideal, even minimally, you will make mistakes. Manually typing on my Google virtual keyboard I keep hitting the period key rather than the space, for.an.effect.like.this, even though as a climber I am quite dextrous with my hands. The Samsung keyboard is easier to use without typos, for me, but the auto correct that comes with it is much worse, so I stick to Google...
@Franny I don't really understand what you're saying exactly.... But you could email NYTGames@nytimes.com If you have concerns.

Thanks.  My concerns in the game app is  1) I can’t clear a word (only the whole puzzle) and 2) skipping forward, it used to stop on a letter if it was in pencil, but now it seems to consider it a filled space.  The other option is to move through each word regardless of whether it is complete or not.  (Hope this makes sense!)

But again, thanks for the address.

@Franny 

As for your first concern, I think I can help you. You can clear a word. Just select its last letter and use the backspace key to delete the word letter by letter. This won't work if you have enabled the Check puzzle option - that prevents clearing any word or letter individually: maybe this is what you are experiencing?

You can also change the puzzle view to a list of clues and answers - the option is on the toolbar at the top. That works for reviewing all entries.

The pencil thing: there is nothing I can say to help you with that, sadly.

Hope this helps 🙂

@Franny I don't use the app and have no problem getting to the archive. (Android phone) I have been mildly annoyed when a day's puzzle is gone from the main screen  but it's always been in the archive.
  but go to tech support by all means.

@Mike 
I just tumbled to the fact that you wear the pun crown.

Mike,

Water you getting at with that far-fetched comparison?

(It’s giving me a headache… where’s my brown paper?)
@Petrol Same, but I used only the Down clues! Very straightforward.

@Andrzej 

I hadn't either. 

And in fact I made a fall stew this very evening. 

Mmmm!
@Carl HOW

@Carl 


How is that physically possible?

@Cam 

Indeed - that would be typing at better than 68 wpm not including clue reading time.

Carl,

The mini?

@Helen Wright 
I do the puzzle first thing in the morning, and today it was almost dark enough to need a lamp at 7:30. It's a little depressing, but a little cozy as well. We're entering the time when the cat refuses to leave my LAP.

@Eric Hougland 

Too cynical, Eric.

The rational is that children are safer when trick-or-treating before sundown.  There are still neighborhoods where they are out on foot on the public streets.

The hazards are more likely to be auto traffic than vampires and werewolves.

@Helen Wright , nodding head in sympathy.

My husband has for many years worked with and for an international industry group. He frequently takes zoom calls at 2 am with Asians or 4 am with Europeans.
Our cat adopted that schedule with alacrity such that hubby now gets up every morning at 4 am to feed her breakfast. She has him trained!
I roll over and get another few hours sleep.
@mld I wonder who Humpty Dumpty might be in the modern era.

@David -- Perhaps sitting in the middle of row two?







Et tu, emu.

@David 

President Jimmy Carter could not put it together again after the OPEC oil embargo and the Iranian hostage crisis.

His fall had nothing to do with his character or personal integrity.

Unlike that of a former mayor of NYC once hailed as "America's mayor".

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: First a Sunday from December 16, 1979 by Michael Priestley with the title "Through the looking-glass." A couple clue/answer theme examples: "Egghead." HTPMUDYTPMUH "Look-alikes." EEDELDEEWTDNAMUDELDEEWT (23 Letter grid-spanner). Some other theme answers: NEEUQDEREHT RETTAHDAMEHT YKCOWREBBAJ And there was no 'reveal' in that one other than the title of the puzzle. Don't recall ever finding another one like that. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=12/16/1979&g=26&d=D ...

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened again: A Thursday from September 4, 2003 by Nancy Salomon and Bob Peoples. That one had 13 rebus squares, with the rebus in every one of them being "UM." Some sample answers: H(UM)PTYD(UM)PTY AL(UM)IN(UM)FOIL VACC(UM)P(UM)P D(UM)DAD(UM)D(UM) L(UM)PS(UM) And there were a few others. Here's the Xword Info link for that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/4/2003&g=17&d=A I'll shut up now. ...

@Skeptical1 

You're missing the point of the Monday puzzle. It's supposed to be easy. People who have never solved crosswords before need puzzles like these to get into crosswording. When I was familiarizing myself with NYT grids 1,5 years ago, Mondays were the only puzzles I could deal with, and not easily, either. But they were doable, and learning to deal with them made me then tackle Tuesdays, etc.

Also, after the often brutal weekend puzzles, an easy Monday is a very welcome change of pace even for many a seasoned solver.

Ultimately, if you don't like Monday puzzles, you can skip them, no?

Calls like yours are quite common in the gaming community, btw. There are those who frown at easy difficulty levels in games, and they call on developers to make all games uber hard, all of the time. The thing is, not everybody likes being challenged all of the time. You can't expect all games to conform to your idiosyncratic preferences.

@Skeptical1 You'd be surprised at how difficult it can be to create a crossword suitable for a Monday, which welcomes all solving levels. Let's drop the bot accusation and start recognizing the hard work of constructors, please!

@Skeptical1 My impression, after reading innumerable comments over the years is that the construction difficulty for a Monday is high. The expectation is that everyone will get a gold star so the job is to make it challenging but only mildly so. Early week puzzles provide the best chance for a personal best and for a lot of us that’s where the fun is.
@Cam The thing that most surprises me about these very fast times is people how type that fast, or even read that fast.

@JLP60615 

Preach!
@JLP60615 Does it matter if the word is capitalized? Merriam-Webster seems to thinks so. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/bible
@CindyM There are multiple ways to enjoy something.

@CindyM Ditto. Why want the fun over before you've even finished the first cup of coffee? I always try Mondays on downs-only for that reason. (I can only do about half of them that way in the end and am not ready to try any other days that way.)
@CaptainQuahog But after so much previous kerfuffle, I was sure it had to be OCTOPODES after all.

@RozzieGrandma 
Though probably not on a Monday. :-)

@CaptainQuahog,

The first thing I thought of when I saw 2D:

“Captain Quahog will be happy!”



Finally, they got it right!

@RozzieGrandma - OCTOPodes is not really a very common English pluralization, although it would not be wrong and I would welcome it in a crossword. We use it in taxonomy and systematics, but it's more of a specialized usage. 

We also use OCTOPODs to refer to the group. But that wouldn't be a very common pluralization in regular English.

@John Carson 

What, you haven't heard of the harvest festival sponsored (they say) by cops everywhere?  Were you trying alternative spellings, my little PUNKIN?  Did the thought of all the varieties make your eyes glaze over?

@Mean Old Lady 
Strands #239
“Fall fun”
🔵🔵🔵💡
🔵💡🔵💡
🔵🟡

Ah!  It worked.   Back when dinosaurs roamed the Earth I worked as an Orchard manager during the time when we began to realize that, if we were to survive as East Coast operations we needed to get into the entertainment business which involved things like mazes, pick your own, etc.  

No one could survive strictly as a wholesale grower because the Pacific Northwest and other, less humid areas, had better growing conditions.  

But for me doughnuts did not ring true as a particular orchard offering.  But I may be missing something.   Feel free to educate me.
